p: Tyrosinase (EC 1.14.18.1) is a ubiquitous enzyme containing two copper ions. The dinuclear copper center of tyrosinase catalyzes the o-hydroxylation of monophenols, oxidation of catechols [ 138, 139], quinonization of dihydroxycoumarins [ 140], o-aminophenols and aromatic o-diamines [ 141]. Tyrosinase is also one of the key enzymes in melanin biosynthesis. In animals, as the enzyme catalyzes the first two main steps of the melanogenesis. Overproduction of melanin can result in various hyperpigmentation disorders including melasma and age spots. Thus the discovery of new tyrosinase inhibitors has been since many years the main goal of numerous investigations [ 142, 143]. Many studies deal with chemical compounds extracted from plants. Even though the presence of phenolic compounds in plants of the genus Lamium is abundant, and potentially there are many phenolic compounds able to influence the activity of tyrosinase, there are very few studies that describe such an influence on the tyrosinase enzyme.
